PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
1.  Project preparatory technical assistance (PPTA) totaling $500,000 of grant funds1 is 
included in the 2010 SARD pipeline. 
 
A.  Justification 
2.  PPTA is necessary in order to conduct proper due diligence on technical, economic, 
financial, social and environmental aspects of the Program as well as the tranche 1 subprojects. 
Needs assessments for capacity building of the executing agency (EA) are also required, as 
well assistance in preparing the requisite framework documents for the  MFF. 
 
B.  Major Outputs and Activities 
3.  The outputs of this PPTA are a fully prepared MFF and Tranche 1 loan. This includes 
completed  social  and  environmental  analysis  and  documentation,  technical,  economic  and 
financial due diligence, and a well designed capacity development and implementation support 
component.

C.  Cost Estimate and Proposed Financing Arrangement

a  grant  basis  by  the  Japan  Fund  for  Poverty  Reduction,  and  administered  by  ADB.  The 
Government will provide the remaining $50,000 equivalent on an in-kind basis. The detailed 
cost estimate is presented in Table A5.4.

D.  Consulting Services 
6.  Consultants will be engaged in accordance with Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
(April 2010, as amended from time to time). Individual consultants will be engaged, consisting of 
8 positions and 23 person-months.2 Work to be performed by consultants includes assisting 
ADB with (i) a detailed executing agency capacity assessment, and suggested remedial action 
plan to build executing agency and implementing agency capacity to minimize procurement and 
financial  management  risks;  (ii)  support  in  bidding  document  preparation  and  preparing  a 
procurement  plan  for  the  tranche  1  loan,  (iii)  preparation  of  social  safeguards  framework 
documents, and social safeguards due diligence for the tranche 1 subprojects including census 
surveys, consultations and preparation of a resettlement plan, (iv) preparation of environmental 
safeguards framework documents, and environmental safeguards due diligence for the tranche 
1 subprojects including consultations and preparation of an initial environmental examination, 
(v)  economic  and  financial  viability  due  diligence  on  the  tranche  1  subprojects,  and  (vi) 
preparation of a capacity development program for the EA to be implemented throughout the life 
of the MFF. 
                                                
2 The reason for individual consultants is because certain key positions must be in place quickly in order to meet the 
project processing deadlines requested by the Government of India.  The remaining positions would then not be as 
important to be hired as a group from a single firm.

7.  The outline terms of references for the project preparatory TA consultants are described 
in paragraphs 8 to 15.  
 
8.  Transmission  Engineer  &  Team  Leader  (international,  5  person-months).  The 
consultant will have a degree in electrical engineering, and experience working in India on 
electric transmission system planning. Knowledge of ADB loan processing is essential, as this is 
not only a technical position but a team leader passion for MFF and tranche 1 loan processing. 
The  consultant  would  review  EA  operational  and  planning  capabilities  and  make 
recommendations for capacity development activities to be part of the MFF. The consultant will 
also review the detailed project reports (DPRs) and confirm that the proposed transmission 
investments  are  consistent  with  the  state’s  transmission  system  master  plan.  Preparing 
technical descriptions of the tranche 1 loan subprojects and working with the EA to ensure 
proper  electrical  diagrams  are  produced  to  illustrate  and  delineate  the  subprojects.  The 
consultant would also review the overall transmission master plan and ensure the roadmap and 
investment/financing plan is consistent with the master plan, and recommend changes, as 
required.  
 
9.  Financial Specialist (corporate level) (national, 3 person-months). The consultant will 
conduct the financial assessments at the corporate entity level, related to HPPTCL's financial 
management  arrangements,  complete  the  ADB  Financial  Management  Assessment 
Questionnaire,  and  prepare  a  financial  management  assessment  report,  recommending 
measures that will improve the financial performance of EA, including tariff adjustments, better 
cost-recovery  mechanisms,  cost-control  measures,  adjustments  to  capacity  addition  and 
investment programs. 
 
10.  Project  Economics/Financial  Assessments  Consultant  (international,  3  person-
months). The consultant will conduct the economic and financial assessments for the Tranche 1 
subprojects in accordance with ADB’s Financial Management and Analysis of Projects (2005), 
using the financial internal rate of return method and comparing it with the relevant weighted 
average cost of capital. The consultant will also convert all financial prices into economic prices 
and conduct economic analyses in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for Economic Analysis of 
Projects. The consultant will also perform a detailed tariff analysis and review the existing 
regulatory framework in Himachal Pradesh and assess how this affects the investment projects 
financially and economically.  
 
11.  Environment Specialist (national, 4 person-months). The consultant will prepare an 
Environmental Assessment and Review Framework for the proposed Program in accordance 
with  ADB's  Safeguard  Policy  Statement  (2009),  review  the  detailed  project  reports  and 
environmental reports, if any, for the proposed investment components in the Tranche 1 loan, 
conduct site visits to the subproject areas including holding consultations as require, and 
prepare  Initial  Environmental  Examination  (IEE)  reports  for  the  respective  transmission 
investments in accordance with ADB's Safeguard Policy Statement (2009).

5 
 
 
12.  Social Safeguards Specialist (international, 4 person-months). The consultant will 
review the national legal policies on land acquisition and involuntary resettlement to verify 
adequacy  and  consistency  with  ADB's  Safeguard  Policy  Statement  (2009)  in  terms  of 
involuntary  resettlement  and  indigenous  peoples,  and  if  gaps  are  found,  recommend 
measures to bridge the gap. The consultant will prepare a Resettlement Framework and 
Indigenous People’s Development Framework in full consultation with the stakeholders, and 
prepare a Resettlement Plan (RP) for the Tranche 1 subprojects in full consultation with the 
stakeholders,  and  each  in  accordance  with  ADB's  Safeguard  Policy  Statement  (2009), 
Operations  Manual  F1/BP  and  F1/OP  (2010),  and  relevant  local  laws,  policies  and 
regulations. This will require organizing field investigations including questionnaire interviews 
in the subproject areas, consulting with relevant officials from the government and other 
organizations to supplement available secondary data, preparing a poverty profile of the 
subproject  area.  Furthermore,  the  consultant  will  engage  in  a  consultative  process  with 
women  and  affected  groups,  and  collect  socioeconomic  data  in  the  relevant  adjacent 
communities, and identify potential gender, social, employment generation, and health impact 
issues. 
 
13.  Institutional Specialist (national, 2 person-months). The consultant will conduct the 
intermediate  and  longer  term  needs  assessment  in  institutional  capacity  in  regards  to 
commercial,  financial  and  regulatory  activities,  and  in  corporate  and  managerial  planning, 
including reviewing HPPTCL's institutional capacity for carrying out commercial, accounting, 
financial  and  regulatory  related  activities.  The  consultant  will  identify  the  presence  of  any 
institutional capacity development programs that are in implementation or are to be undertaken 
over the next 3 years by stakeholders, including central and state government programs or 
other agencies and assess how these programs would meet HPPTCL’s institutional capacity 
requirements. Based on the above, identify existing gaps and recommend immediate and longer 
term  solutions  including  basic  management  information  systems,  required  capacity 
enhancement and identify training needs that would need to be met for the installation and 
operation of such systems. In addition, the consultant will assess the policy framework of 
Himachal Pradesh and recommending modifications, if any, to further promote transmission 
investment and viability of the state’s transmission utility company.  
 
14.  Procurement Specialist (international, 2 person-months). The consultant will conduct a 
procurement capacity assessment and support HPPTCL in bidding document preparation in 
accordance with ADB procurement guidelines.  
 
15.  Planning System Software Specialist (international, 1 person-month). The consultant 
will review the state’s transmission system master plan as modeled on power system planning 
software (CYME proprietary software). The consultant will work with HPPTCL to update the 
master plan as required and ensure all proposed subprojects are properly reflected in the 
system computer model. The consultant will prepare diagram maps as required for the MFF’s 
and Tranche 1’s proposed subprojects. 
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  The executing agency (EA) for the TA is HPPTCL, and assisting HPPTCL in forming a 
project management unit is envisaged as part of TA activities. The EA will provide in-kind 
contributions by providing office accommodation, support facilities, counterpart staff, maps, 
reports, and other logistical support.
